I gave up asking for a new room, and sat in coffee shops for warmth. LA had unusually cold temps, but that's still no excuse for not having a functional heater. To make matters worse, my room smelled like mildew and old trash. I should have switched rooms just for that (they ignored that request too), but I discovered by wandering around that the ENTIRE hotel had an old, unclean smell to it, like trash, cigarettes, and mildew. Housekeeping comes by early, and if you are not ready for them by 10:30am, they stick a nasty-gram under your door. Of course, I wasn't planning to be in my room that much, considering the cold and the smell, but on the two occasions I decided to return after breakfast to make a phone call and pick up some items, they let me know that I was not welcome to linger. Also, there were only two pillows on the bed, no extra blanket, and I could not get more when I asked the housekeeping staff. Parking is not easy, but be careful! The front desk will tell you it's cheaper to park with them, but if you park in the Little Toyko Mall parking garage, which is the SAME BUILDING, they will charge you less than half of what the Miyako charges. It cost me $62 for 8 days of parking; the Miyako was going to charge me $136 ($17/day for self park, $24/day for valet). What makes me frustrated most about the stay is not the poor service at the front desk, but the lost opportunity. The hotel could have had so much to offer. The shiatsu massage was one of the best I've ever had, though the spa was dirty and the reception was not very helpful and seemed stressed. The cafe in the lobby was convenient and offered good food and service. Even the gift shop clerk was friendly and nice. Best of all was the location -- in the heart of Little Toyko, it's close to public transportation, downtown activities, a huge selection of restaurants, and has a wonderful view of city hall. I enjoy the Japanese culture and was looking forward to this visit. It's a shame that the Miyako Hotel had such poor execution. I am a quiet, respectful guest who never complains and I travel frequently on business. This is the first time I felt motivated to write a review and warn others. My recommendation: Stay here for the location, the local restaurants, and the shiatsu massage. Have a high tolerance for the cold and damp, and be able to ignore bad smells and awful service. The rates aren't low enough to account for the poor treatment of guests. And despite what I read, I did not encounter any language problems, only attitudinal.

Reviews.Title: “Stay somewhere else”
Reviews.Author: sisigirl
Reviews.Content: I had an unpleasant and unsatisfactory experience in Miyako. I made my reservation online at Miyako official website. I reserved King size bed. When I checked in, I got 2 double beds instead. The gentleman at the front desk told me that room-type is not guarantee when making the reservation. When I made my reservation online, I was required to enter my credit card information. Quote from the website: “All reservations require a valid credit card number and expiration date in order to guarantee your reservation”. I didn’t see anything that says room-type is not guarantee when I made my reservation. I told the gentleman at the front desk that I am not happy with the 2 double beds. He then told me that the room that they assigned to me (the 2 doubles) is a free upgrade to deluxe/luxury. I asked him what is the difference between a basic and a deluxe/luxury room. He told me the furniture are better. My room # was 405 and I am NOT convinced that it is a deluxe/luxury room. Why? Part of the desk is a just a piece of dark brown wood attached to the wall with no leg. Another desk with light brown color serves as an extension of the dark brown wood on the wall. Not to mention the desk has major scratches and dents all over. I did not want to waste my time to go back to the front desk and ask for a room switch. My conclusion is I will not stay in Miyako again and I will not recommend this hotel to anyone. There was another unpleasant experience during my stay in Miyako. When I went back to the room the next day, the cleaning crew left a dirty towel on the floor inside the room.

Reviews.Title: “overpriced”
Reviews.Author: pettaspagna
Reviews.Content: The hotel is quite overpriced. Position is good, but you pay for the internet, you pay for the parking because it's not free ... breakfast is not included. For all these reasons, i found this hotel expensive, even though the position is good and secure, and the hotel is clean and nice.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay.”
Reviews.Author: Maugter
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Miyako in February, for 11 days. Staff was as friendly as can be, everything was clean inside the hotel, the room was more than large enough for the both of us and complete with a large bed. People were always smiling and happy to help. Considering location Miyako may not be a quite as fortunate as other hotels, but with a metro straight down the road, you can be anywhere within 30 mins. The area seemed safe and if you like sushi you'll be even more happy seeing as they have alot of that kind (it is Little Tokyo after all). A great stay and should I go to LA again, I would probably choose Miyako once more.

Reviews.Title: “Great for frequent travelers”
Reviews.Author: txsteveh
Reviews.Content: The Miyako is one of those hotels not to many people seem to know about. I travel often to Los Angeles,30 weeks or more out of the year on business, and find my self trying new hotels all the time. This hotel has been consistent with every stay and is always a good place rest. The rooms are quiet, clean, and good sized. The executive rooms do offer a nice big LCD TV and upgraded bed which is nice for a small +$20 or so a day. The +$20 still makes this one of the most affordable hotels around the downtown area. The staff is great and know who I am when i walk in and the little coffee shop downstairs is great. They also have a couple very good restaurants as well as a gym and massages. Little tokyo is right next door where there is another 20 or so restaurants to choose from. All in all I never mind staying here when on business. I must have stayed here no less then 15 weeks the last 12 months and I have never had any issues.

Reviews.Title: “Clean Place, Friendly Staff”
Reviews.Author: jodcha
Reviews.Content: I won a bid for this hotel thru Priceline for $75/night. Most sites rate this hotel 3-star, Tripadvisor rate this 2-star. Hotel exterior looks old, but once you step in, it's a different story. The lobby is bright and clean and spacious. Parking was ~$20 per 24-hour. Its valet. I had a good experience, because they upgraded us to "Tokyo Executive Room". What a surprise even I booked this thru Priceline. Apparently, there were two groups of tour (from Japan I guess) checked in before us (We checked in really late night), thus all standard/deluxe rooms had been taken, we got an upgrade. The room was very good, bed very comfy, nice decor, given that I only paid $75 for an executive room in downtown LA, it was a very good deal. But I am not sure if I would say the same thing if I was in a standard room. Due to the fact that the hotel was fully booked that night, the problem was, there was not enough hot water. And that is the only thing I would complain. Water from the shower head was not strong and water wasn't even warm... I managed to finish my shower. When it was my boyfriend's turn, hot water was all gone, we called the front desk and ask for help. They allowed him to shower @ the Spa with no charge. Surpringsly, Spa has "unlimited" hot water for him to enjoy! and he also used the sauna. His experience was "OK". Staff were all very friendly, except for one lady. They all put on a smile and tried their best to make you happy. Neighbourhood was good. Felt very safe @ late night. I am a Chinese and love Japanese food, the area has a lot of choices! Overall, this is a good hotel, and I would consider going back if I win this thru priceline again.

Reviews.Title: “Nice place to stay. friendly and clean.”
Reviews.Author: pearlroad
Reviews.Content: Stayed there in a king size single room 1001. Top floor in the corner. Never heard a peep from anyone. Nice size, clean bathroom. The tv channel selections were the only downfall but hopefully you are not there for that. DVD player was also included. Attentive staff. Good room service. Across the street to a line of great asian restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “Very Unfriendly Experience”
Reviews.Author: raynej58
Reviews.Content: I stayed there from 1-4-08 to 1-6-08, and I have to tell you this was my worse hotel experience. First, i got there in the middle of a torrential rain, and was soaking wet when I got there. they have no shuttle from the Union Station, nor do they offer one, so I had to walk all the way there. When I checked in, as dripping as I was, no one offered me any towels, nor any way to dry my clothes (they have washers & dryers, but no one made mention of this to me). After going to my room, I noticed that the rooms have a DVD player in them (no one mentioned this either), with instructions on how to obtain a rental. I went to the Front Desk and asked about a rental, and they sent me across the street to Paradise Video to rent a DVD. After going across the street (still torrential rain coming down), they store tells me they ONLY carry Japanese DVD's. No English at all. Of course when I got back to the hotel the Front Desk looked surprised, and I found out later it was because they understood very little English. They had no complimentary newspaper (though they had Japanese newspapers at the Front Desk, all others were outside in the machine). They have NOTHING complimentary, and they even tried to close the washer/dryer room at their normal time (10:00 p.m.), even though it was still pouring outside (couldn't dry my clothes). The Fitness Center charges $20 to use the facilities, and there was nothing the hotel wanted or offered to do for me, even though I stated my grievances with them as well. There were no English food places in the area except for Subway & Togos sandwich Shops. the problem with that was no one in the hotel knew this, and I didn't find out until I had walked all around in the rain (for 20 mins) until I found them. this hotel is very English "Unfriendly"!!! If you aren't Japanese, you have nothing coming. Nothing wrong with the culture, but their site should state this information, and the Staff should at least know what's going on around there. This hotel is listed as a 3 Star Hotel, but it is barely a 2 Star. I had the worse time of my life there.

Reviews.Title: “Bargain with a great neighborhood feel”
Reviews.Author: techconfgoer
Reviews.Content: Outwardly, the New Miyako has a strong 80s aesthetic. Inside, the rooms are really clean and comfortable. There was even a bidet and a warmed toilet seat - very Japanese! I came for a Msft show at the LA Convention Center. While it is a bit far too walk, you can easily drive and park there. The fact that your hotel will be much cheaper than something nearby - I paid $109 a nite, during a huge convention, mind you - shows you how much you'll probably save. Also, the hotel is in the midst of Japantown and sandwiched by a gentrifying loft area to the east and a trendy club area rising to the west nearer to downtown. So it's a great location, and very safe. The Japanese ramen place across the street, Daikokuya, is a Mecca for Asian noodle lovers. You'll probably get a ticket for a complimentary continental breakfast at the downstairs cafe, Take 5. Take advantage - while it's a bit carb heavy for my taste (croissant etc.) in the morning, the coffee, filtered using some exotic Japanese technology that leaves fine little bubbles, was delicious.

Reviews.Title: “Great Location”
Reviews.Author: N_and_R
Reviews.Content: I went to Los Angeles for a work-related conference, which was held at the convention center. I am not a big fan of the neighborhood around the LA convention center because there's really a lack of a neighborhood feel around it. Also, there is a lack of reasonable food options around the convention center. Instead of staying too far from the convention center, we decided to stay in Little Tokyo, which is relatively close to the convention center. Being a big fan of Japanese food and culture, it was a perfect solution to our problem. The hotel itself, however, was not as nice as I hoped. Basically, we got what we paid for. Our room was clean and relatively functional, but was very small. No special amenities. The doornob, I think, was in need of repair. However, free internet access was great. We had a great government rate deal (I workk for a public benefit corporation for the state of New York) which included a room, free internet, free "continental" breakfast, and a visit to their spa. However, by no means we felt "unsafe." In terms of safety, I would feel much less safe around the convention center. If this hotel was located in a boring neighborhood, I would never recommend this hotel to anyone. However, for those who will be going to LA for a convention, I highly recommend staying at Miyako instead of any of the typical "convention hotels." The hotel is centrally located in Little Tokyo, more centrally so than other hotels. We found too many wonderful places to shop and eat around the hotel than any other hotel we have ever stayed in our travels. We had breakfast mainly in their "Take 5" lobby cafe, but we tried the Japanese style buffet breakfast in their 2nd floor "Tamon" restaurant twice. The breakfast was pretty good, since it was either part of the package at "Take 5" or discounted at "Tamon." However, I think it is sort of silly to stay in the hotel for your food, since there are a lot of options just outside the hotel. Also, the hotel is very close to a couple of museums (Japanese American National Museum and MOCA Geffen), both of them are worth visiting. The spa area on the third floor is clean and nice, probably not the nicest spa I have been to. I may not recommend it unless it is "free." There is a coin operated laundry area, also on the third floor. In summary, I highly recommend this hotel to anyone who needs to stay in downtown LA, especially for conventions. What Little Tokyo offers more than makes up for a old and tired look of the hotel, as well as their quirky customer service. However, if you have no interest in Japanse food and culture, this location is probably not recommended.

Reviews.Title: “Some Good, Some Not-So-Good”
Reviews.Author: leclaire68
Reviews.Content: The Miyako wouldn't have been my first choice of places to book ... but the rate was good and I'm always interested in trying new places. In some places you can find it rated 3-stars, other places 2-stars. In my opinion, it is much closer to a 2-star property. The lobby is nice, valet parking was efficient, and the in-hotel spa ($20 for guests) was decent. The rooms, though, reminded me a bit of a tired low-quality chain hotel. The windows are small (I had a view of the parking structure behind the hotel), the carpets were a tad stained and dusty in the corners, and the sink in the bathroom was chipped. The tub's grout was stained and chunks were missing, too. It wasn't anything that made my stay horrible or anything, but it did let me clearly know that I was not in a true 3-star property. On a side note, the bathroom was equipped with a Japanese bidet and heated toilet seat system. Interesting! The one big gripe I had was the bed. The bedding was fine, but the mattress was provided by Lucifer himself, I'm sure. I felt every spring, especially those the lined up oh-so-perfectly with my rib cage. Since one books a hotel to sleep, I found the bed to be quite a disappointment. On the whole, the Miyako could be a much better hotel with a small to medium sized infusion of cash. Right now, it just comes off as a cheap imitation and not a place to call "home" for very long.

Reviews.Title: “should be a 1 star”
Reviews.Author: grebo007
Reviews.Content: I paid 140 dollars for 1 night to get a room that was small and had no a/c. The room got really stuffy and couldn't sleep all night! The bedding was dirty and so were the towels. I can't believe expedia rated this hotel as a 3 star..The room quality was dated..Not to mention the 19 dollar parking fee plus 2 dollar tip..So the total cost 161 plus 3 bottle waters= 164.00. Are you kidding me? Oh yea I also got sick from not sleeping..Not a good trip needless to say...!!

Reviews.Title: “Tries to punch above its weight - not a 3*”
Reviews.Author: Maxing-n-Relaxing
Reviews.Content: I stayed a couple of nights at the Miyako. The lobby is the nicest part of the hotel, if only because of the marble floor and sliding glass doors. The rooms are spartan and a bit dated, basically a bit less nice than a Holiday Inn Express or Howard Johnson. Apparently you can pay extra for a better furnished room - but why not just stay at a nicer hotel if you want to pay more. The room was clean and a reasonable size. In the bathroom the shower head was at an unreasonably low height (this is a Japanese hotel). In terms of facilities, the "coffee shop" is crammed into one corner of the lobby and the "shop" is in another. The "business centre" is a small room (I hesitate to say broom cupboard) off to the side. There is no swimming pool and the "spa" facilties cost extra (one reason I think this hotel is not a 3*, which some travel websites list it as). I found the staff a bit mixed. One front desk agent was overall polite but a little surly, but two other ladies were very polite. The big plus point from my point of view was free overnight parking on the street right outside. You have to circle the block a couple of times to get a space, but it saves on the $18 the hotel charges. Overall this isn't a bad hotel, there are just nicer places to stay.

Reviews.Title: “No sleep hotel!”
Reviews.Author: NEWYORK1961
Reviews.Content: In town for business,booked for 3 nights close to my! meeting,rooms are ok!but if you want to get a goodnite of sleep avoid this place because on 3rd floor there is a karoke bar/OJAH BAR thats open allnite,you hear the loud noise allover the hotel,i spoke to the gm he told me that's how it is!very rude!so i checked after i nite!

Reviews.Title: “Not bad for lone female traveller.”
Reviews.Author: WonderSAdven
Reviews.Content: This hotel was not bad for the money. The room was clean and the staff was friendly. I was a young female staying alone for business and I didn't feel unsafe. The worst thing was the rooms were not very well lit and upon entering the lobby it smelled horribbly like fish. However, the rooms did not smell. The staff was quite friendly but there was a bit of a language barrier. They had many papmplets available at the desk for tourist attractions in the area. Free parkng and close to major freeways. Overall, I would stay in the hotel again. The other hotels in the area were much more expensive in comparision.

Reviews.Title: “Great place to stay at a good price”
Reviews.Author: continent-hopping
Reviews.Content: Located in downtown LA, it is good value for the money. For the tourists who don't have a car, the subway is 2 blocks away (12 minutes' walk) and takes you directly to Hollywood and Universal Studios, where all the tourist attractions are. For tall people (over 6 foot or 180cm), the bed may be too small. Otherwise, it is a great place to stay. Clean and tidy. Much better than motels, and just a bit less than the Hilton. Will definately stay there again. And if you need an internet connection for working, take the rooms with DSL, they are worth it!

Reviews.Title: “If you're in that area, it's THE place”
Reviews.Author: museum8888
Reviews.Content: If you need or want to stay downtown and near Little Tokyo, you can't beat it. I had business meetings very nearby, so it was the logical choice for me (since I didn't want to bother with a car), but I was ultimately impressed by the room and staff. I booked through an online room broker and when I called the day before my arrival to confirm the reservation, the hotel staff had no information--yet. (The broker ended up not faxing my reservation until the day of arrival.) In any case, during the phone calls before the reservation came through--when I was a nervous wreck--the front desk staff was unfailingly polite and also advised me on how to resolve the issue. The common areas of the hotel are very clean, and my room was spotless. There were small nicks in the furniture, and this is clearly not a new hotel, but the room was spacious and well-appointed. The snack bar in the lobby had quite a selection of drinks, sandwiches and snacks and is open long hours, and there are some fun sushi shops right around the corner. It's kind of a scruffy neighborhood, but I did not feel unsafe. The rates are also extremely reasonable.

Reviews.Title: “great location”
Reviews.Author: Leesw8
Reviews.Content: Pleasantly surprised by the hotel - ideal for downtown, and despite the other reviews, we felt very safe in the area. We did use the valet parking option at $16 per night. Rooms were basic and fine. Breakfast was included with the AAA rate, which was not great and we did not have it everyday - it was served at a sort of cafe in the lobby.

Reviews.Title: “Ridiculous Parking and not safe location”
Reviews.Author: Anna1201
Reviews.Content: I travel all the time and this was the worst experience I have had regarding service. The hotel itself is nice and cute with good rooms. My problem is the location........freaking scary. The only "safe" area is standing in front of the hotel and the few restaurants across the street. If you walk around the block it is covered with homeless people and not safe at all. Also the parking is a freaking joke. If you don't get your tickets validated every time, you can't leave the garage. I asked if they can call the hotel and verify my room, they said no. I even had a sheet that the hotel asked me to fill out stating I was paying the daily rate of $14 and she the parking attendent said no. I had to go back to my room, go down to the lobby, get my ticket validated then get out of the garage. By the way, the garage is NOT connected, you have to walk in a narrow corridor to get to it through a dark passageway. Are you kidding me????? I will never ever stay here again. I even spoke to the manager about it, and they said that's just how it is. I should be able to put a flyer on my vehicle to show that I piad for parking and just have the attendent open the gate, just like many other hotels do. About the rooms, the bed is a rock, but I liked it.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel for the money in spite of the location”
Reviews.Author: PatrickTravels
Reviews.Content: For one night in LA I was looking for an affordable hotel but one that wasn't too "tired" nor in a scary neighborhood. I was interested in the Miyako as a "pre-Japan immersion" but had no need to be downtown. My first choice was the Travelodge in Santa Monica on Pico. I've stayed there before and like the hotel and location. When I compared prices about a month before the trip the Travelodge was $99 and Miyako was $109 plus approx $20 for parking. Then about two weeks before the trip I checked again and the prices were switcehd; Miyako at $99 (via their website) and Travelodge at $109. Hence we stayed at the Miyako....and it was a very pleasant experience. Finding the hotel was easy as was valet parking. Desk clerks were fine and yes they speak English. I have no idea what other reviewers were talking about. The clerk also upgraded us to a business room that was fnatastic and very nice. He even went out ofhis way to tell us about the immigrant march planned for the next day and gave us a map with the route and any parking resirctions. He even gave some guidance on driving away from the march area. He was very helpful. We didn't eat at any of the restaurants. There's a Starbuck's-style coffeee place off the lobby but instead I walked to a real Starbuck's two blocks away (west?, left out the door) at the Otani. Neighborhood is tired afterall it is downtown LA so there weren't really any otpions for dining. THen again it's LA so hop in the car and drive somewhere.

Reviews.Title: “Heart of Little Tokyo-Close to Amtrak Station”
Reviews.Author: LaubsMom
Reviews.Content: My husband and I recently did some traveling via Amtrak. We had an overnight stay in Los Angeles so I chose a Hotel that would be close to the Amtrak station. The Miyako is in Little Tokyo, I did realize this when I made the reservations but didn't realize what the situation would be. Much of the information in the room was in Japanese so I couldn't read about anything that the Hotel had to offer. We arrived rather late in the evening. The hotel lobby was a little scary to me at first and I was really worried that I had made reservations to stay there. Our room was ok, nothing special. I really did enjoy the linens on the beds though. They also had down comforters, something you don't find in a lot of hotels these days. They do charge for phone calls, even when you have a calling card. I had to get the front desk to allow my call by giving my credit card number to them once again. Most Hotels where I have stayed do not charge for calling card calls. It wasn't a big deal just somewhat of an inconvenience. The following morning I made a trip to the lobby and was surprised by the difference from the night before. They have a gift shop and a small cafe that was opened and it really helped brighten up the look of the lobby. I had hoped to check out some nearby restaurants while we were there since we had time before we needed to catch the train but my husband wasn't that comfortable so we just headed back to Union Station.

Reviews.Title: “What a nice surprise! Would stay again...”
Reviews.Author: gottagosomewhere
Reviews.Content: I was very surprised of the value and quality of this hotel for a regular room. For the same price elsewhere, for example in or near Hollywood, I would have not been able to get such a nice and quiet room. I would stay at this hotel again. Good: +Quiet and clean room +Reasonably priced +Room is great for singles, couples, etc +Wireless +Nice white duvet with down comforter +Subway station: 4.5 blocks to Civic Center Subway Station (can get to Hollywood/Universal in 20mins) +Close to financial district—can walk or take modern city shuttles for 25 cents +Unique area-Little Tokyo +Coffee shop within 1.5 blocks-Starbucks (at New Otani Hotel) +Japanese supermarkets nearby offering snacks, bottled water, alcohol and other foods +Staff were friendly and helpful +Nice lobby and corridors +Airport Flyaway Bus to/from Union Station for $3 (Union is one stop from Civic Center Station or you can walk from the hotel in approx. 15 minutes. There is also a metro bus that can be taken close to the hotel that goes to Union station for $1.25) Poor: -Shower was not of hotel standard, although the rest of the washroom was fine. Later I didn't worry much about the shower-wasn't such a big problem. -Lack of restaurants except for Japanese ( but this is understandable for the area being Little Tokyo. Some of these restaurants were only so-so. Other notes: Some travelers mentioned about the homeless in the area. I did see about 4 a day walking by but they kept to themselves. Basically, the area is not that bad at all but I imagine the further east you go, for example East 4th street and San Pedro, it may be a different story yet there is really no need to go to that area. The funny thing is even in Beverly Hills I saw a homeless man, so go figure. Also, I read from others that the beds are very firm. The truth is that they’re a little on the firm side but not as much as one would think by reading these posts. It’s definitely true for your back to sleep on more of a firm bed than an overly soft one. And, I actually did sleep very well. No problems at all with this.

Reviews.Title: “Fine hotel for downtown tourist”
Reviews.Author: lite2shine
Reviews.Content: I stayed here during Veterans weekend. I wanted to attend the Japanese American Natural History Museum across from the hotel, so I wanted to stay here so that we don't need to drive a short distance if we stayed other hotels in downtown. The lobby area is small as well as the hotel room (I stayed at a standard room) but it was clean and fine. I don't think their restaurant or breakfast was great for the price but don't eat at the hotel as there are many restaurants in Little Tokyo just around the corner. Caution: the area around the hotel isn't that bad, but you don't want to go down the 3rd street/olive. I forgot to turn on Olive and suddenly I was driving in a skid row.

Reviews.Title: “Don't be scared. This place is fine.”
Reviews.Author: jrscribbler
Reviews.Content: Agree with the last few reviews. I booked on Priceline and was a little nervous after reading the hatchet jobs on here. Checked in and, as someone who stays in downtown LA on business a lot, I can tell you the place was totally fine. Sure, you could do a lot better but you could definitely do a lot worse. Rooms are small and clean, service was fine, and the price was right. It's not a particularly nice or fancy place -- personally, I don't know if I would give it 3 stars. Two, or maybe 2 1/2 if we're being picky. And it has a few advantages -- free high-speed internet is great, and if you've stayed in downtown LA before you know that at $15/day for valet, parking is frankly a bargain. It ain't the Four Seasons but if you just need a place to lay your head for a few days and you can get a good rate, the Miyako is a completely adequate option. No bad experiences to report at all.

Reviews.Title: “Room with a 10th Floor View”
Reviews.Author: RoadWarriorChris
Reviews.Content: Well, I don't know what's going on on floors 1 through 9, or really, what's up with all the vitriol of some of the other reviewers, but up here on 10, I have a view of the mountains, a very comfy bed (a strong contender to all the biz chains' bedhead/heavenly etc. offerings), well-appointed surroundings, cool mini-soap to add to my collection (may I never purchase toiletries again!) and a Buddhist text in addition to your ubiquitous Gideon's Bible. Daddy like. I can't imagine bedbugs in this room. Look -- I upgraded (from the standard room booked through PL immediately upon checking-in) based on previous reviews, but honestly, I can't imagine a tiered level of service/accommodation here that could be that extreme. The obligatory list of cons (on the business tip): 1) No available outlets near the work desk. 2) When I'm done working, why can't I ever (in the Miyako, the Hilton, or the Hyatt) watch the few shows I enjoy on TV? It's 2006 -- why am I still limited to Discovery, Oprah and HBO? Sorry, that's an ongoing gripe. Death to OnCommand. That's it. I usually have a few more. Bottom line: This hotel's average review is erroneously slated way too far towards the negative. I would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “ok hotel”
Reviews.Author: yukoy
Reviews.Content: Stayed 2 nights in July '06. Ok for $89/night. Free fridge in the room was great. Room was fine too. Only thing was the water. It smelled like sewage water. I made coffee with this water and tasted bad too. When I made coffee with same coffee packet at Hotel Otani a couple days later it was fine so it must have been the water at Miyako. Has free high speed internet. Good for the price if you can book it for less than $100/night. If not, Otani is better.

Reviews.Title: “Bad faith. Won't stay again.”
Reviews.Author: visitor1095
Reviews.Content: Booked room through PLine. Asked for non-smoking. Gave me smoking, smelly room overlooking busy street. Blamed this on late booking. I believe this was not because the non-smoking rooms were booked, as the hotel seems uncrowded and not busy, but because of the priceline booking. Poor location of self park in public lot distant from rooms, elevator. Room in bad shape. Cigarette burns in table. Stained chairs. Bathroom in bad shape, cracked tile, cracked sink. Someday, someone will file a class action against priceline/these hotels which typcially do not provide the three or four star class advertised by priceline. Further, priceline does not notify purchasers that parking is not free.

Reviews.Title: “Good Enough For Short Stay”
Reviews.Author: travellator
Reviews.Content: Stayed here one night with three family members after getting a pretty good deal with Priceline. Check-in was easy and all our dealings with the staff was courteous and quick. Space felt a bit small with four adults and our baggage. The room and bathroom felt slightly worn, but it wasn't much of an issue to us, though it may be to others. I agree with other reviewers when they say that it's not AS nice as it shows in the hotel's website. As for location, it is in downtown LA which isn't a particularly convenient spot if you're doing the touristy things, which we were, and LA traffic doesn't help the distance. The front desk explained both the valet and self-serve parking options. We used the hotel's valet, which was easy and quick, even though it cost more than the self-serve parking around the block. All in all, we were satisfied with our stay, especially considering what we spent and the time we were there. Though i'm not sure I would choose a downtown hotel to base my stay in LA as a tourist.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed my stay very much”
Reviews.Author: alertvideo
Reviews.Content: Stayed 5 nights at the Miyako a couple of weeks ago and enjoyed it. All things considered it compared favorably (minus the restaurants) to my stay at the Westin Bonaventure in late June. It IS in Little Tokyo and definitely has a Japanese feel to it - I don't understand why this surprises people. My room was above average and comfortable. The efficient and friendly staff made my stay a good one and I would stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “make sure you get a nonsmoking room”
Reviews.Author: allady
Reviews.Content: I got this room through Expedia, asked for a non smoking room. Arrived and there were no nonsmoking rooms available, except for $40.00 more. We visited the smoking room, which was on the smoking floor and didn't make it more than 2 steps into the room, before we were overcome by the smell. Take a Vegas casino and multiply it by 10,000 and you have the level of stench. Never have I encountered a worse smell. It would have been unbreathable, so we couldn't stay there. The hotel would not cancel the reservation or refund the money, but Expedia made good on the deal. No monetary loss, but it was 4pm and we had no room. We stayed at the Days Inn, cheaper, bigger room, great bathroom, smokefree, free breakfast, friendly, helpful people and $4.00 a day parking. You do the math.

Reviews.Title: “Glorified Motel 6!!”
Reviews.Author: littlejoy
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Miyako for just one night, which is good, because that is all I could handle! We got a cheap price on Priceline, thank goodness, as I would never pay full price for this hotel. I would be extremely upset if we had to pay more than our $50 on priceline. Our standard room was very plain, no decor on walls, just the headboards. I did check for bedbugs, but all seemed ok there-Shower heads are made for people on the shorter side, and bathrooms needed to be upgraded a bit. Peeling wallpaper, chipped paint in sink, and faucets didnt work too well. Could hear neighbors every time they took a shower or flushed toilet.The valet parking fee was high, $15, but so is all the parking in downtown LA, so I was expecting it. The one thing I did like was that the rooms had a DVD player, which was great for my 3 yr old. Staff was pretty friendly, the bellhop guy, who took our luggage up to our room, was extremely friendly, and even made us a map, with good,local sushi resteraunts. I wouldnt want to stay here again, but if you are looking for a decent room with just a place to lay your head, this will suffice.

Reviews.Title: “Miyako Hotel, Japanese for Cheap Motel 6!!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed at this dump for one night, although the rate was cheap through priceline, you are fore warned, you definitely get what you paid for, or maybe less, yes, definitely less. In all my years of using priceline, this was by far the worst hotel I have every stayed in, simply awful. O.k, in all honesty, it did serve its purpose, if you really need a bed for a night, but you have my sympathy if you are in this dump for more than one night. Where do I start, if your over 6' tall, you will definitely know what its like to be Shaq!! The rooms are so small, I kid you not, you will feel like a 7 footer, so small that the ironing board was the right height for my 7 year old....I'm still laughing about that, no kidding...at 6'2, the shower head literally came to my chest!! The staff is definitely not very friendly and the parking spaces are a joke and then some.. Park next door at the Little Tokyo Mall indoor parking lot, its $6.00 over night, but you don't have in and out privileges. I honestly was happy that I only had to stay here one night. I read reviews that said this place wasn't bad...PLEASE!!!!!!! Again, if you really only need a room for a night, and you don't give a (you know what), this place is o.k., but the feeling is cheap, although the lobby as stated earlier does look nice, HOWEVER, the rooms are cheap, in much need of remodeling and then some....Awful best describes it...I did not notice any bed bugs, which had been a major complaint among others. Whatever you do, please do not expect much with these rooms, they are really a poor man's Motel 6, so definitely leave the light on!!! This was the first time I ever was in a hurry to check out, seriously!!! The whole time I was here, I was wishing I had two more hands, to give this place four thumbs down!!!!! Its definitely catered toward Vietnamese and midgets!! On a scale of 1 - 20, I'd probably give this place a 3, and thats being generous!! believe me, I'd avoid this place if I were you!! Don't be fooled folks, this place is a one, no better yet no-star hotel!!! I have seen better Motel 6 & Red Roof Inns, I would never stay here again, and that's the truth! Avoid at your own risk!!!

HotelInfo.Name: Miyako Hotel Los Angeles
HotelInfo.Address: 328 East First Street, Los Angeles, CA 90012-3902
